payload.instructions:
## Skills
These skills are discovered at startup from multiple local sources. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions.
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
- Discovery: Available skills are listed in project docs and may also appear in a runtime "## Skills" section (name + description + file path). These are the sources of truth; skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Description as trigger: The YAML `description` in `SKILL.md` is the primary trigger signal; rely on it to decide applicability. If unsure, ask a brief clarification before proceeding.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deeply nested references; prefer one-hop files explicitly linked from `SKILL.md`.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

content.text:
# AGENTS.md instructions for d:\Game builds\Pixel Pal

<INSTRUCTIONS>
## Skills
These skills are discovered at startup from multiple local sources. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions.
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
- Discovery: Available skills are listed in project docs and may also appear in a runtime "## Skills" section (name + description + file path). These are the sources of truth; skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Description as trigger: The YAML `description` in `SKILL.md` is the primary trigger signal; rely on it to decide applicability. If unsure, ask a brief clarification before proceeding.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deeply nested references; prefer one-hop files explicitly linked from `SKILL.md`.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.
</INSTRUCTIONS>

# Context from my IDE setup:

## Open tabs:
- PROMPT_AGENT_3_PERFORMANCE_ENGINEER.txt: .agent/staging/PROMPT_AGENT_3_PERFORMANCE_ENGINEER.txt
- PROMPT_AGENT_2_SECURITY_AUDITOR.txt: .agent/staging/PROMPT_AGENT_2_SECURITY_AUDITOR.txt

## My request for Codex:
::: TRIBUNAL PROMPT (AGENT 1: ARCHITECT) :::

**YOUR ROLE:** ARCHITECT (Codex 5.2 Model)
**INPUT:** Read the attached 'SYSTEM_STATE.md' file.
**TASK:** IMPLEMENT Track 1: Component Composition.
1.  Create `src/frontend/components/GameCanvas.tsx`.
    - Must implement the "Composition Root" pattern.
    - Initialize `GameLoop`, `InputManager`, `SceneManager` in a `useEffect` (simulated, assumes classes exist or you can stub them).
    - Ensure strict isolation: No React state triggering Canvas renders.
2.  Create `src/frontend/components/HUD/HUDOverlay.tsx`.
    - Position absolute over the canvas.
    - Contain placeholders for `StatusBar` and `ActionBar`.

---
## ðŸ›‘ REQUIRED OUTPUT PROTOCOL (NON-NEGOTIABLE)

REGARDLESS of your task outcome (Success, Failure, or Partial), you **MUST** generate a completion report.

1.  **Target File:** `.agent/staging/responses/AGENT_1_ARCHITECT.md`
2.  **Content Requirements:**
  - **Header:** `# REPORT: AGENT 1 (ARCHITECT)`
  - **Summary:** Implemented GameCanvas and HUD.
  - **Deliverables:** Full code for `GameCanvas.tsx` and `HUDOverlay.tsx`.
  - **Status:** [COMPLETE]

**FAILURE TO WRITE THIS FILE IS CONSIDERED A TOTAL FAILURE OF THE TASK.**

# SYSTEM STATE SNAPSHOT

**Timestamp:** 2025-12-27T22:18:00-05:00
**Task:** EXECUTE Phase 3 Code (Gameplay Implementation).
**Context:** The Planning Phase is complete. We have a strict "Tribunal Approved" Implementation Plan. Your goal is to write the code for your specific track.

## ASSIGNMENTS

- **AGENT 1 (ARCHITECT - Codex)**: Track 1. Build `GameCanvas.tsx` and `HUDOverlay.tsx`. Ensure they strictly follow the "Rendering Isolation" rule (React never renders Canvas).
- **AGENT 2 (SECURITY - Gemini)**: Track 3. Build `InputManager.ts`. IMPERATIVE: Implement the "Input Validation" logic (clamping, deadzones) defined in the Security Report.
- **AGENT 3 (PERFORMANCE - Opus)**: Track 2. Build `useGameState.ts` and `GameStateStore`. Implement the 10Hz throttling mechanism.
- **AGENT 4 (QA - GLM)**: Track 4. Build the Test Suite (`inputManager.spec.ts`) to verify the other 3 tracks.

## REFERENCE: IMPLEMENTATION PLAN (STRICT ADHERENCE REQUIRED)

(See attached implementation_plan.md content below)

---

# Implementation Plan - Phase 3: Gameplay Implementation

**Goal:** Connect the `GameLoop` and `AssetLoader` to a React UI, enabling user interaction and state management for the "Pet Tamagotchi" experience.

## Objectives

1.  **UI Integration**: Render the `GameCanvas` component within `App.tsx` and ensure it scales correctly.
2.  **Input Handling**: Implement click detection on the canvas to trigger game events (e.g., petting the character).
3.  **HUD Overlay**: Create a React-based UI overlay for game stats (Happiness, Hunger) and actions (Feed, Play).
4.  **State Synchronization**: Connect the mutable `Character` persistence model to the React UI state.

### Architectural Decisions (Tribunal Verdict)

1.  **Rendering Isolation**: `GameLoop` manages Canvas entirely. React NEVER triggers canvas renders.
2.  **State Throttling**: Use `useGameState` with a **10Hz throttle** to prevent React from stalling the Game Loop.
    - _Source of Truth_: `GameStateStore` (Singleton/Context-free).
    - _Bridge_: `useSyncExternalStore` for selective reactivity.
3.  **Input Handling**: `InputManager` uses **Direct DOM Listeners** (`capture: true`, `passive: false`) to bypass React Synthetic Events (~11ms latency reduction).
    - _Security_: Inputs must be clamped/validated before Game State mutation.

### Component Specification

#### 1. `InputManager.ts` (Performance + Security)

- **Role**: Capture raw DOM events, sanitize, and update `InputState`.
- **Features**:
  - `mousemove`/`touchmove` for pointer tracking.
  - Coordinate translation (Viewport -> Canvas space).
  - **Validation**: Clamp vectors to [-1, 1].

#### 2. `GameStateStore` & `useGameState` (Performance)

- **Role**: High-performance state bridge.
- **Pattern**: External Store (not React Context).
- **Hooks**:
  - `useGameState()`: Full snapshot (debug only).
  - `useGameField(key)`: Selective subscription (HUD).

#### 3. `GameCanvas.tsx` (Architect)

- **Role**: Composition Root.
- **Lifecycle**:
  - Mount: Init `InputManager`, `SceneManager`, `GameLoop`.
  - Unmount: Cleanup listeners.
- **Ref**: Holds persistent instances to survive re-renders.

#### 4. UI Overlay (HUD)

- **Components**: `StatusBar`, `ActionBar`.
- **Optimization**: specific components subscribe only to their relevant data fields (e.g., `sparkles`, `health`).

## STRICT OUTPUT PROTOCOL

You are an external agent participating in a Tribunal.

1. DO NOT return conversational filler.
2. YOU MUST return your response in a Markdown file.
3. Your output must strictly follow the requested Role format.
4. **WRITE THE CODE**. Do not just plan. Return the full file contents.

payload.text:
**Designing GameCanvas and HUDOverlay components with InputManager integration**

Iâ€™m defining the GameCanvas component as a composition root that initializes InputManager, SceneManager, and GameLoop instances within a React effect, carefully managing canvas resizing and cleanup without triggering React renders. Concurrently, Iâ€™ll create a HUDOverlay component with placeholder StatusBar and ActionBar elements styled using Tailwind CSS, designed as an absolute overlay with controlled pointer events. Iâ€™m also preparing to write both componentsâ€™ full code to new files and generate a completion report documenting these changes.

payload.message:
Created the composition-root canvas component and HUD overlay with absolute positioning and placeholders, and wrote the required tribunal report with full code. GameCanvas wires `GameLoop`, `SceneManager`, and `InputManager` in `useEffect` with resize handling and cleanup, while keeping React out of the render loop. See `src/frontend/components/GameCanvas.tsx` and `src/frontend/components/HUD/HUDOverlay.tsx`. The completion report is in `.agent/staging/responses/AGENT_1_ARCHITECT.md`.

Next steps:
1. Wire `GameCanvas` and `HUDOverlay` into the relevant page/layout (per the Implementation Plan).
2. Confirm the API of `src/frontend/game/InputManager.ts` matches the constructor/cleanup calls used here.

content.text:
Created the composition-root canvas component and HUD overlay with absolute positioning and placeholders, and wrote the required tribunal report with full code. GameCanvas wires `GameLoop`, `SceneManager`, and `InputManager` in `useEffect` with resize handling and cleanup, while keeping React out of the render loop. See `src/frontend/components/GameCanvas.tsx` and `src/frontend/components/HUD/HUDOverlay.tsx`. The completion report is in `.agent/staging/responses/AGENT_1_ARCHITECT.md`.

Next steps:
1. Wire `GameCanvas` and `HUDOverlay` into the relevant page/layout (per the Implementation Plan).
2. Confirm the API of `src/frontend/game/InputManager.ts` matches the constructor/cleanup calls used here.
